comments.commentBody: I don't know what the law is in Connecticut but probably the governor, with or without the support of the parole board could commute those death sentences to life. I can't imagine any state executing someone after the law has been repealed.

It is great to see that Connecticut is about to join civilization and end the death penalty. While the exemption for current death row inmates is unfortunate, Connecticut would be the fifth state to abolish the death penalty since 2007 (Illinois, New York, New Jersey, and New Mexico are the other four), and there would now be 17 states in the US that do not have a death penalty.

The death penalty is barbaric, ineffective, biased, and costly. The evidence shows that the death penalty costs taxpayers more than life in prison without parole, does not deter violent crime, and is marred by significant racial bias and far too frequent ineffective legal representation for those who are charged with capital crimes. Since 1973, at least 138 people have been released from death row after being proven innocent, and there are at least 23 cases in the last century of people who have been killed by the death penalty but are now believed to be innocent of the crimes they were killed for.

In short, it is well beyond time for the death penalty to be abolished. We should celebrate if Connecticut does so, thank the officials there who voted to end it, and then work on getting rid of the death penalty in the remaining 33 states and the federal government.

Just yesterday, I flew from ORD to SFO. It took me just as long to get through security at ORD as it did to travel from my hotel in the North Loop area on Wacker Drive to O'Hare on the CTA Blue Line - and that includes the 15-minute walk from the hotel to the subway. Security theater and being patsies for putting up with these inconveniences indeed. But what are our alternatives when we are traveling?

And if we feel safe because a 73-year old woman is pulled aside and tested for chemical residues, then our sense of what makes us "safe" has lost any sense of perspective. But perhaps that's not a surprise. After all, we live in a society in which the Supreme Court rules in a 5-4 decision that it's ok to be strip-searched twice after one is arrested incorrectly for an outstanding traffic warrant that should have been erased. Who can expect any of us to differentiate between measures that truly result in increased safety rather than intrude into privacy and personal liberty solely for the sake of theater if the Supreme Court can't figure it out?

Krugman is talking about the debt burden in the private sector, most importantly mortgage debt which is currently high compared to property values. Even those of us who managed to avoid going "underwater" are unwilling or unable to dip into home equity, which is what fueled much of the growth from 2002-2006.

I'm not sure how you expect that the President, or anyone else is going to reduce that private debt burden. If you are calling for wholesale reduction in principals owed, I'd say you have a good thought. It's a total non-starter given the hold Big Banking has on both parties, but other than a little inflation, I don't see anything else changing things.

Inflation in a macroeconomic sense does seem to hold advantages.  However, what I worry about is that those that don't make a wage that is adjusted to inflation will still make the same wage as necessities increase in price precisely because inflation will make these things tangibly more expensive.  The ideal goal must be to manage inflation in such a way that not only increases the probability that those that hold money or debt actually spend more, but that fiscal policy forces proportional increases in wages tied to inflation.  This is why we are having trouble in America today as the true cause of the recession-- the reduction of purchasing power of the middle class due to job loss, reduced salary, or increased expenses-- has never been resolved.  And with the current status of the U.S. today in political and fiscal terms, I am afraid inflation will only exacerbate this problem.

Some of the more conservative commenters actually have a point in regard to inflation. Given the still high rate of unemployment, wages have been stuck. There would be real pain for working Americans if inflation rises. There's already real pain just from the rise in gasoline prices. So, the Republicans have found some ears for their fear-mongering.

It's a hard political sell to tell those people that their wages will rise once spending and hiring increase after private debt eases. Telling retirees who depend on interest income that they will not see their savings erode, is perhaps an even tougher job.

Given those concerns, and Bernanke's coziness with the investing class, I'm not surprised that he is being overly cautious in regard to inflation fears.

inflationistas invoke peculiar theories, when sticky wages (and a 2% raise in line with the feds target for the rest of us) is all ones needs.

the hawks have held back Bernanke from using his 2003 playbook, based on nonexistent evidence.

its wrong to assume that more aggressive fed action would be inflationary: the evidence is that it would result in real output growth and the hawks superstitions are are unjustified.

its time the fed stopped jerking the brake just as the economy turned. they need to fully commit to a stable path of nominal income growth, including a commitment to close the output gap.

The hyper rich, the plutocrats have, since time immemorial, lived of rents. (In the nineteenth century, hyper rich were called "rentiers", that is, people who perceive rents. The archetype of rents is payments from government bonds) So what they detest is inflation. Work resist to inflation, because work is always needed, so work can always ask for money.

New technology also loves inflation, because it forces people to re-examine their old habits, relative to the new temptations. By killing some (types of) inflation, the technological change was slow down below the danger zone.

By the way, the obsession with inflation started in Europe. The reason is that the hyper rich were able to persuade the French socialists that, to be mature, they had to be anti-inflation. So they fabricated a monstrous machine, the European monetary union, where the states would be financed, not by themselves, but by going begging to the hyper rich private individuals and banks.

".A lot of people--especially those on the right--are animated by fading memories of newsreel footage of Germans wheeling wheelbarrows full of worthless paper currency around, in fruitless hunt of a loaf of bread."

Something that happened only in one year, 1923, after France occupied the German coal mines and took their production to pay war reparations.

The reality is that inflation would increase housing prices and, eventually, wages. It would benefit borrowers by making it easier for them to pay off their debts. Unfortunately, it would do so at the expense of lenders, and its the lenders in the finance industry who are calling the shots.

A small, temporary rise in inflation in exchange for an increase in velocity of money and employment might make sense, but it will get *no traction* unless and until you can convince more (WTD VSP) people that it (a) will work and (b) serves their long-term best interests to get the US economy moving again sooner rather than later

Somebody doesn't seem to understand the idea of compound interest. If we had been running 4% inflation over the last few years, it would be like magically waving a wand and forgiving 15% of what is owed. 15% is a lot of money, and 3 years is not a real long term time frame.

The only debate should be whether the Fed has the ability to put a break on inflation if it starts to go above 4%. Unless you buy into bogus neo-classical economics, the answer is clearly (and historically), yes.
